text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Foreign Minister Siim Kallas said he would leave for a meeting with Yevgeny Primakov in an optimistic mood, hoping that a border agreement would be signed in a month.

- Students are unhappy about a government decision to stop subsidies which allow them to buy half-price bus and train tickets. A protest letter with 3,500 signatures will be delivered to the government today and demonstrations on the roads are planned in the southern city of Tartu.
- Postimees asked for MPs' opinions on the border agreement with Russia. Opinions differ greatly and there is no firm conviction that the parliament would ratify the agreement.
- Parliament's financial commission said most of the changes they had received for the 1997 draft budget were populist and unrealistic.
- Police on Friday found and defused a bomb with three kg of explosive in a hamburger bar in the northeastern town of Johvi and said a catastrophe was narrowly avoided.
- Tallinn city court overruled a government decree from 1995 on non-return of property and decided that one of the leading hotels in Tallinn, the Hotel Palace, should be returned to its legal owner.
